name: ZAYTUNA COLLEGE
mission: Zaytuna College aims to educate and prepare morally committed professional, intellectual, and spiritual leaders, who are grounded in the Islamic scholar...
programs: BA in Liberal and Islamic Studies
Center for Ethical Living and Learning (ZCELL)
theoryOfChange: By training the mind through the trivium and quadrivium alongside Islamic primary texts, the college produces leaders who can navigate modern society with moral and spiritual grounding.

evaluationSources: Accredited by WASC Senior College and University Commission (WSCUC)

zakatClaimEvidence: Zaytuna College has a dedicated "Zakat Fund" which "serves as the basis of our financial aid program and is utilized to cover the total cost of educating a zakat-eligible student." Their donation page also lists "Zakat" as a designation option. Furthermore, Zaytuna College states, "Our current policy has been reviewed and approved by senior scholars, such as His Eminence, Shaykh Abdallah bin Bayyah, one of the foremost Muslim jurists of our time." (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFjZj9ls_cjqCGjOz6eZFuG61o14U90v849aIFKq70HibgYbOkoGffibqnMwxT3dACx93CKPa24x3a9jM9KOL-lyj1S_BLH_qG1d3w_b86pidZZRlpr8_6Xxu6IhR4d3IQD1T3U)

score_details.score_summary: ZAYTUNA COLLEGE earns 49/100 due to moderate impact and moderate alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a total revenue of $18,359,667 and a program expense ratio of 56.0%.
Financial records indicate a fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised and working capital of 33.6 months.
Zaytuna College offers a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies and a Master of Arts in Islamic Texts.
The institution maintains its status as an accredited liberal arts college.
The college's mission is to prepare morally committed professional, intellectual, and spiritual leaders.
The curriculum is designed to ground students in the Islamic scholarly tradition and the Western cultural heritage.
The college is a zakat-eligible organization and provides various methods for donor contributions.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The college earns a moderate overall score due to its strong financial reserves and unique educational niche, balanced against a program expense ratio that suggests significant overhead or administrative costs.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 56.0% is lower than industry benchmarks for direct service
Limited public data regarding specific long-term student career outcomes

dimension_explanations.alignment: Zaytuna College provides a medium fit for donors interested in global education and Islamic scholarship, offering a track record of academic rigor within the American higher education landscape [4][7]. Its status as a zakat-eligible institution aligns with the specific religious giving requirements of many Muslim donors [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The college focuses on capacity building by educating future leaders through its accredited undergraduate and graduate programs [3][6]. While it maintains a robust total revenue of $18,359,667 and significant working capital of 33.6 months, its program expense ratio is 56.0%, indicating that a substantial portion of funds is directed toward non-programmatic operations [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Zaytuna College is the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the United States, dedicated to grounding students in both Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.
strengths: High financial stability with 33.6 months of working capital
Exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised
Maintains formal accreditation for its unique liberal arts curriculum
baseline_narrative.summary: Located in Berkeley, California, Zaytuna College offers specialized degree programs including a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies and a Master of Arts in Islamic Texts [3][4]. The institution operates as a zakat-eligible entity, focusing on the development of morally committed intellectual and spiritual leaders [8].

areas_for_improvement.context: The <cite id="7">program expense ratio of 56.0%</cite> is below the <cite id="18">industry standard of 75%</cite>, suggesting a high portion of funds is directed toward administrative or capital reserves.

case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="7">56.0% program expense ratio</cite>, which indicates that nearly 40% of revenue is spent on non-programmatic costs.

alignment.improvement: Alignment could be improved by <cite id="25">adding a dedicated zakat page</cite> that highlights the humanitarian dimensions of its scholarship programs.

credibility.explanation: Zaytuna maintains high credibility through its <cite id="13">WASC accreditation</cite> and <cite id="17">Candid Gold Seal</cite>. Governance is supported by a <cite id="16">12-member board</cite> and <cite id="20">independent audits</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the college could <cite id="21">document a clearer theory of change</cite> with explicit causal pathways for its educational outcomes.

impact.improvement: The college should <cite id="23">track and report beneficiary counts</cite> to enable a more precise cost-per-student analysis.

rich_narrative.headline: Zaytuna College is the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the United States, dedicated to grounding students in both Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value long-term Islamic institutional building and want to support the academic development of future American Muslim scholars.
donor_motivations: Want to support the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the US
Value the synthesis of Islamic and Western intellectual traditions
Prefer supporting established institutions with high financial stability
giving_considerations: Gifts contribute to a large-scale institutional endowment and campus
Program efficiency is lower than emergency relief charities
Focus is on long-term leadership development rather than immediate humanitarian aid
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate, high-efficiency humanitarian relief or those who prefer small, grassroots community projects.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The college provides verified academic outcomes through its <cite id="13">accreditation status</cite> and published catalogs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Zaytuna creates impact by providing a rigorous dual-tradition education to students who then serve as leaders in various professional and spiritual fields.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Accreditation ensures that the educational services provided meet national standards of quality and rigor.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the college has significant assets, its <cite id="15">19.7% growth rate</cite> suggests ongoing expansion needs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="13">formal WASC accreditation</cite> and larger <cite id="4">$18.3M revenue scale</cite> compared to peers.

strengths.detail: The college maintains <cite id="6">33.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a robust buffer against economic volatility.
Zaytuna spends only <cite id="10">$0.11 per $1 raised</cite>, significantly outperforming many non-profit peers in resource acquisition.
The college is <cite id="13">accredited by the WASC Senior College and University Commission</cite>, validating its academic rigor.

strengths_deep_dive: Zaytuna College's primary strength lies in its institutional maturity and financial resilience. With <cite id="14">net assets totaling $42,577,802</cite> and a <cite id="15">3-year revenue CAGR of 19.7%</cite>, the college has successfully scaled its operations since its inception. This growth is supported by a <cite id="16">12-member board of directors</cite> and a <cite id="17">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, indicating strong internal governance and a commitment to public disclosure.
rich_narrative.summary: Zaytuna College, <cite id="1">founded in 2009</cite> in Berkeley, California, represents a landmark in American Muslim education as the first <cite id="2">accredited Muslim liberal arts college</cite> in the United States. The institution's mission is to prepare morally committed leaders through a curriculum that bridges <cite id="3">Islamic and Western scholarly traditions</cite>. Financially, the college reported <cite id="4">total revenue of $18,359,667</cite> in 2023, with a significant portion of its funding coming from <cite id="5">$15,266,326 in contributions</cite>. While the college maintains <cite id="6">high financial stability with 33.6 months of working capital</cite>, its <cite id="7">program expense ratio of 56.0%</cite> is notably lower than the <cite id="8">peer program ratio median of 78.4%</cite> for global education organizations. Despite this, the college demonstrates <cite id="9">exceptional fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending only <cite id="10">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite>. Zaytuna is <cite id="11">zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing donors to support students across categories such as <cite id="12">fuqara (the poor) and masakin (the needy)</cite> through its specialized scholarship funds.
